title: Chapter 6 Quiz: Wireless Networking
description: Comprehensive quiz covering WiFi standards, frequencies, channels, security protocols, authentication methods, and wireless troubleshooting

questions.question: Which Wi-Fi standard supports both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz frequencies and introduced MIMO technology?
questions.explanation: 802.11n (Wi-Fi 4) was the first standard to support both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz frequencies and introduced MIMO (Multiple Input Multiple Output) technology. It can achieve up to 600 Mbps. 802.11g only supports 2.4 GHz, while 802.11ac is 5 GHz only. 802.11ax (Wi-Fi 6) came later.

questions.question: What is the maximum theoretical speed of Wi-Fi 6 (802.11ax)?
questions.explanation: Wi-Fi 6 (802.11ax) has a maximum theoretical speed of 9.6 Gbps across multiple streams using advanced modulation (1024-QAM) and OFDMA. Real-world speeds are typically much lower. 802.11ac (Wi-Fi 5) maxes at 6.9 Gbps, and 802.11n at 600 Mbps.

questions.question: Which 2.4 GHz channels do NOT overlap in North America?
questions.explanation: In the 2.4 GHz band, only channels 1, 6, and 11 do NOT overlap in North America (channels 1-11 available). Each 2.4 GHz channel is 20 MHz wide but spaced only 5 MHz apart, causing overlap. Using non-overlapping channels prevents co-channel interference in adjacent access points.

questions.question: What advantage does the 5 GHz frequency band have over 2.4 GHz?
questions.explanation: The 5 GHz band has significantly more non-overlapping channels (up to 24 in some regions) compared to only 3 in 2.4 GHz. However, 5 GHz has shorter range and worse penetration through obstacles. 2.4 GHz travels farther and penetrates better but has more interference from microwave ovens, Bluetooth, and other devices.
references: Lesson 52: Wireless Frequencies - 2.4 GHz vs 5 GHz

questions.question: Which Wi-Fi 6 technology allows multiple devices to transmit simultaneously to an access point?
questions.explanation: OFDMA (Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiple Access) in Wi-Fi 6 allows multiple devices to transmit simultaneously by dividing channels into smaller resource units. MU-MIMO allows simultaneous transmission to multiple devices but not from them. OFDMA significantly improves efficiency in dense environments with many devices.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a wireless site survey?
options: Count the number of wireless devices
Determine optimal AP placement and coverage
questions.explanation: A wireless site survey maps RF coverage, identifies interference sources, and determines optimal access point placement, channel assignments, and power levels. It ensures proper coverage without dead zones or excessive overlap. Site surveys use specialized tools to measure signal strength (RSSI), SNR, and interference.

questions.question: Which wireless security protocol is considered obsolete and should never be used?
questions.explanation: WEP (Wired Equivalent Privacy) is completely broken and can be cracked in minutes using freely available tools. It uses weak RC4 encryption with 40-bit or 104-bit keys. WEP should never be used. Modern networks should use WPA2 (minimum) or WPA3 (preferred) with AES encryption.

questions.question: What encryption algorithm does WPA2 use?
questions.explanation: WPA2 uses AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) with CCMP (Counter Mode with CBC-MAC Protocol) for strong encryption. WEP used weak RC4, and WPA used TKIP (also RC4-based but with improvements). AES is a symmetric block cipher considered secure and is required for high-security networks.

questions.question: Which WPA3 feature protects against brute-force dictionary attacks on passwords?
questions.explanation: WPA3 uses SAE (Simultaneous Authentication of Equals), also called Dragonfly, which replaces WPA2's PSK (Pre-Shared Key) handshake. SAE is resistant to offline dictionary attacks even with weak passwords. WPA3 also provides forward secrecy and uses 192-bit encryption in Enterprise mode.

questions.question: What is the difference between WPA2-Personal and WPA2-Enterprise?
questions.explanation: WPA2-Personal uses a Pre-Shared Key (PSK) that all users share. WPA2-Enterprise uses 802.1X authentication with individual credentials validated against a RADIUS server, providing per-user authentication, accountability, and easier credential management. Both use AES encryption.
references: Lesson 53: Wireless Security - Personal vs Enterprise

questions.question: Which protocol is used for centralized authentication in enterprise wireless networks?
questions.explanation: RADIUS (Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service) is the standard for enterprise wireless authentication with 802.1X. Users authenticate with individual credentials (username/password or certificates) validated by the RADIUS server. RADIUS also provides accounting and supports multiple EAP methods.

questions.question: Which EAP method provides mutual authentication using digital certificates for both client and server?
questions.explanation: EAP-TLS (Extensible Authentication Protocol - Transport Layer Security) requires certificates on both client and server for mutual authentication, making it the most secure EAP method. PEAP uses server certificates only. EAP-TLS is complex to deploy due to certificate management but provides strongest security.

questions.question: What is the purpose of PEAP (Protected Extensible Authentication Protocol)?
options: Create a secure tunnel for credential transmission
questions.explanation: PEAP creates an encrypted TLS tunnel using a server certificate, then transmits credentials (typically MSCHAPv2 or GTC) securely through the tunnel. This protects credentials from eavesdropping. PEAP is easier to deploy than EAP-TLS since only the server needs a certificate, not every client.

questions.question: Which 802.11 standard introduced Wi-Fi 6E with support for the 6 GHz frequency band?
questions.explanation: 802.11ax (Wi-Fi 6) was extended to Wi-Fi 6E with 6 GHz band support, providing up to 1200 MHz of additional spectrum and up to 7 non-overlapping 160 MHz channels. This dramatically reduces congestion. 802.11be is Wi-Fi 7 (future). The 6 GHz band is less congested since it's new.

questions.question: What is a rogue access point?
options: An AP with weak security settings
An unauthorized AP connected to the network
An AP in a different building
questions.explanation: A rogue access point is an unauthorized AP connected to your network, often installed by employees for convenience without IT approval. Rogue APs bypass network security controls and can allow unauthorized access. Wireless intrusion detection systems (WIDS) scan for rogue APs. An evil twin is a rogue AP impersonating a legitimate one.
references: Lesson 55: Wireless Security Threats - Rogue APs

questions.question: What attack involves an attacker creating a fake access point with the same SSID as a legitimate network?
questions.explanation: An evil twin attack involves creating a fake AP with the same SSID as a legitimate network, often with stronger signal to lure clients. When clients connect, the attacker can intercept traffic or steal credentials. Evil twins are difficult for users to detect without comparing MAC addresses or using certificate-based authentication.
references: Lesson 55: Wireless Security Threats - Evil Twin

questions.question: Which wireless security feature should be disabled because it can be easily exploited?
questions.explanation: WPS (Wi-Fi Protected Setup) using PIN method has a critical flaw that allows brute-force attacks in hours. The 8-digit PIN is validated in two 4-digit halves, reducing possible combinations dramatically. WPS should be disabled on all APs. PBC (Push Button Configuration) WPS is less vulnerable but still not recommended for enterprise networks.

questions.question: What is the purpose of disabling SSID broadcast?
questions.explanation: Disabling SSID broadcast (hidden SSID) provides minimal security through obscurity - the network name is still easily discovered using packet capture tools since SSIDs are sent in other management frames. It's NOT a security control but may reduce casual visibility. Hidden SSIDs can actually cause connectivity issues and are not recommended as a primary security measure.

questions.question: Which wireless controller architecture has all management and data traffic flow through the controller?
questions.explanation: Centralized (tunneled) architecture routes all AP data traffic through the wireless controller using CAPWAP or similar tunneling protocols. This allows centralized policy enforcement and visibility but creates a potential bottleneck. Distributed architecture has APs forward data locally. Autonomous APs operate independently without a controller.

questions.question: What protocol is commonly used for communication between lightweight access points and wireless controllers?
questions.explanation: CAPWAP (Control And Provisioning of Wireless Access Points) is the standard protocol (LWAPP was the predecessor) for communication between lightweight APs and controllers. It carries both control traffic (AP configuration, management) and optionally data traffic (client data). CAPWAP uses UDP ports 5246 (control) and 5247 (data).

questions.question: Which type of antenna provides 360-degree coverage in all horizontal directions?
questions.explanation: Omnidirectional antennas radiate signal equally in all horizontal directions (360 degrees) but have limited vertical coverage, creating a donut-shaped pattern. They're ideal for indoor coverage and point-to-multipoint outdoor scenarios. Directional antennas (Yagi, parabolic dish, panel) focus signal in one direction for longer range.

questions.question: What is channel bonding in wireless networks?
options: Combining adjacent channels for higher bandwidth
questions.explanation: Channel bonding combines adjacent channels to increase bandwidth. 802.11n supports 40 MHz channels (2 x 20 MHz), 802.11ac supports up to 160 MHz (8 x 20 MHz). Wider channels provide higher speeds but reduce available channels and increase interference. Channel bonding is more practical in 5 GHz due to more available channels.

questions.question: What wireless troubleshooting issue is caused by too many access points transmitting on the same or overlapping channels?
questions.explanation: Co-channel interference occurs when multiple APs on the same or overlapping channels interfere with each other, reducing performance. This is common in dense deployments. Solution: use non-overlapping channels (1, 6, 11 in 2.4 GHz), reduce AP power, or use 5 GHz which has more channels. Adjacent-channel interference occurs on nearby but not overlapping channels.

questions.question: A user reports weak Wi-Fi signal. You verify the signal strength (RSSI) is -80 dBm. How would you characterize this signal?
questions.explanation: Signal strength guidelines: Excellent (-30 to -50 dBm), Good (-50 to -60 dBm), Fair (-60 to -70 dBm), Poor (-70 to -80 dBm), Unusable (below -80 dBm). At -80 dBm, connectivity may be marginal with frequent disconnections. Note that dBm is logarithmic and negative, so -30 dBm is much stronger than -80 dBm.

questions.question: What is the recommended SNR (Signal-to-Noise Ratio) for VoIP over wireless?
questions.explanation: For VoIP over wireless, SNR should be 25 dB or higher to ensure call quality. General guidelines: >40 dB (excellent), 25-40 dB (good for VoIP/video), 15-25 dB (adequate for basic data), <15 dB (poor). SNR measures signal quality relative to background noise. Higher modulation rates (256-QAM, 1024-QAM) require higher SNR.

questions.question: Which common household device operates in the 2.4 GHz band and can cause wireless interference?
questions.explanation: Microwave ovens operate at 2.45 GHz, directly in the 2.4 GHz Wi-Fi band, and can cause significant interference when running. Other sources include Bluetooth devices, baby monitors, wireless cameras, and older cordless phones. DECT cordless phones typically use 1.9 GHz. 5 GHz Wi-Fi has less interference from these devices.

questions.question: What is RF attenuation?
options: Loss of signal strength over distance or obstacles
questions.explanation: Attenuation is the loss of signal strength as it travels through air or penetrates obstacles. Materials affect attenuation differently: air (minimal), drywall (low), brick/concrete (medium), metal/water (high). Free-space path loss increases with distance and frequency. 5 GHz attenuates more than 2.4 GHz, resulting in shorter range.

questions.question: Which wireless security threat involves flooding APs with deauthentication frames to disconnect clients?
questions.explanation: Deauthentication (deauth) attacks send spoofed deauthentication management frames to disconnect clients from APs. This is a denial-of-service attack and is also used to capture WPA handshakes for offline cracking. IEEE 802.11w (Protected Management Frames) protects against deauth attacks by encrypting management frames.
references: Lesson 55: Wireless Security Threats - Deauth Attacks

questions.question: What does IEEE 802.11w provide?
questions.explanation: IEEE 802.11w provides Protected Management Frames (PMF), encrypting management frames like deauthentication and disassociation. This prevents deauth attacks and man-in-the-middle attacks. PMF is mandatory in WPA3 and optional in WPA2. It protects unicast and multicast management frames using AES encryption.

questions.question: Which tool would you use to analyze wireless traffic and detect security issues?
questions.explanation: Wireless packet analyzers like Wireshark (with appropriate adapters), OmniPeek, or tcpdump capture and analyze wireless frames to troubleshoot connectivity issues, identify security threats, and optimize performance. They can capture 802.11 management, control, and data frames. A wireless adapter in monitor mode is required.
references: Lesson 58: Wireless Troubleshooting Tools - Packet Analyzers

questions.question: What is the purpose of a captive portal on a wireless network?
options: Redirect users to authentication or terms acceptance page
questions.explanation: A captive portal redirects unauthenticated users to a web page requiring authentication, payment, or terms acceptance before granting network access. Common in guest Wi-Fi (hotels, airports, coffee shops). Captive portals work by intercepting HTTP/HTTPS requests until the user successfully authenticates.

questions.question: Which wireless topology has clients connecting directly to each other without an access point?
questions.explanation: Ad-hoc mode (IBSS - Independent Basic Service Set) allows devices to connect directly without an AP. Also called peer-to-peer wireless. Infrastructure mode uses an AP. Mesh networks have APs connecting to each other wirelessly. Bridge mode connects two wired networks wirelessly. Ad-hoc is useful for temporary connections but less common today.

questions.question: What is roaming in wireless networks?
options: Moving between APs while maintaining connectivity
Connecting to networks in different countries
questions.explanation: Roaming allows clients to move between APs seamlessly while maintaining connectivity. Fast roaming standards (802.11r, 802.11k, 802.11v) reduce roaming time from seconds to milliseconds, critical for VoIP and video. Same SSID and security settings across APs enable roaming. Roaming happens when signal drops or a stronger AP is detected.

questions.question: Which IEEE standard improves roaming by providing neighbor AP information to clients?
questions.explanation: 802.11k (Radio Resource Management) provides neighbor AP reports so clients can quickly discover and evaluate nearby APs for roaming without scanning all channels. This reduces roaming time. 802.11r (Fast Roaming/FT) speeds authentication during roaming. 802.11v allows APs to suggest better APs to clients. Together they enable seamless roaming.

questions.question: What is the purpose of power save mode in wireless clients?
options: Reduce battery consumption by sleeping between transmissions
questions.explanation: Power save mode allows battery-powered devices (laptops, phones, IoT) to sleep their radios between transmissions. The AP buffers frames for sleeping clients and sends a beacon indicating buffered data. Clients wake periodically to check beacons. This significantly extends battery life but may slightly increase latency. WMM Power Save improves this.
references: Lesson 56: Wireless Features - Power Save Mode

questions.question: Which frequency is used by Wi-Fi 6E that was not available in previous Wi-Fi standards?
questions.explanation: Wi-Fi 6E extends 802.11ax to the 6 GHz band (5.925-7.125 GHz), providing up to 1200 MHz of spectrum with 59 channels (twenty-four 20 MHz, twelve 40 MHz, six 80 MHz, or three 160 MHz channels). This is clean spectrum with no legacy devices. 60 GHz is used by 802.11ad/ay (WiGig), not Wi-Fi 6E.

questions.question: What is MU-MIMO?
options: Multiple users connecting to multiple APs
Multi-User Multiple Input Multiple Output for simultaneous transmission
questions.explanation: MU-MIMO (Multi-User MIMO) allows APs to transmit to multiple clients simultaneously using spatial multiplexing. 802.11ac introduced downlink MU-MIMO (AP to clients), and Wi-Fi 6 added uplink MU-MIMO (clients to AP). This increases efficiency in dense environments. Clients must support MU-MIMO to benefit. Up to 8 clients simultaneously in Wi-Fi 6.

questions.question: What does beamforming do in wireless networks?
options: Creates separate SSIDs for each device
Directs signal toward specific clients for better performance
questions.explanation: Beamforming uses multiple antennas to focus the wireless signal toward specific clients rather than broadcasting equally in all directions. This improves signal strength, throughput, and range for those clients. It's implicit in 802.11n and explicit in 802.11ac/ax. Beamforming is most effective when both AP and client support it.

questions.question: Which wireless authentication method requires a server certificate but not client certificates?
questions.explanation: PEAP (Protected Extensible Authentication Protocol) requires only a server certificate to create a secure tunnel, then authenticates clients with usernames/passwords (MSCHAPv2) inside the tunnel. EAP-TLS requires both server and client certificates. PEAP is easier to deploy than EAP-TLS but less secure. WPA2-PSK doesn't use certificates.
references: Lesson 54: Wireless Authentication - PEAP vs EAP-TLS

questions.question: What is the main benefit of using a wireless controller versus autonomous access points?
questions.explanation: Wireless controllers provide centralized management, configuration, and monitoring of multiple APs from a single interface. Features include unified configuration, automatic channel/power optimization, seamless roaming, guest networks, and troubleshooting tools. Autonomous APs require individual configuration. Controllers scale better for large deployments but add cost and complexity.

questions.question: Which wireless security control limits which devices can connect based on hardware addresses?
questions.explanation: MAC filtering creates an allow or deny list of MAC addresses that can connect to the AP. However, it provides weak security since MAC addresses are easily spoofed. MAC filtering is administrative overhead for large networks and not recommended as a primary security control. Use WPA2/WPA3 and 802.1X instead.

questions.question: What is the maximum distance for 802.11ac (Wi-Fi 5) outdoors with line of sight and directional antennas?
questions.explanation: With proper directional antennas and line of sight, 802.11ac can achieve several kilometers outdoors (2-5 km typical, up to 10+ km in ideal conditions). Indoor range is much shorter (30-50 meters typical) due to obstacles. 2.4 GHz travels farther than 5 GHz due to better penetration and lower free-space path loss.

questions.question: A company wants to isolate guest wireless traffic from internal corporate network. What feature should they implement?
questions.explanation: VLAN segmentation separates guest wireless traffic from corporate network by assigning guest SSIDs to a different VLAN with restricted access (Internet only, no internal resources). This is critical security best practice. Typically combined with captive portal authentication and bandwidth limits for guests. Corporate SSIDs use 802.1X authentication on separate VLANs.

questions.question: Which wireless standard can achieve up to 46 Gbps and is also known as Wi-Fi 7?
questions.explanation: 802.11be (Wi-Fi 7) is the next-generation standard achieving up to 46 Gbps using 320 MHz channels, 4096-QAM modulation, and Multi-Link Operation (MLO). It operates in 2.4, 5, and 6 GHz bands. MLO allows simultaneous transmission on multiple bands. Wi-Fi 7 is expected to be ratified in 2024 with devices available shortly after.

questions.question: What does RSSI measure in wireless networks?
options: Signal strength received by the device
questions.explanation: RSSI (Received Signal Strength Indicator) measures the signal strength received by a device, expressed in dBm (negative values, e.g., -50 dBm). Stronger signal = less negative number. RSSI doesn't account for noise. SNR (Signal-to-Noise Ratio) is more important for quality. RSSI is useful for troubleshooting coverage and AP placement.
